posts.name: Ryan Morash
posts.cooked:
I am very used to using forks to collaborate in Git, so I was somewhat confused when the team that I started to mentor had each individual contributing to their own branch of the repo.

How do other teams usually use Git?

Forks Branches for each subsystem Branches for each contributor 0 voters

Forks Branches for each subsystem Branches for each contributor

Forks

Branches for each subsystem

Branches for each contributor

0 voters

0 voters

0 voters

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Option 4: Branch for each feature, like any other professional software team

posts.name: Ryan Morash
posts.cooked: Mozilla doesn’t use branches for features: mozilla-central: Branches

Those are Mercurial branches from 2013. Take a look at their GitHub:

This technology could fall into the right hands. Mozilla has 2446 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.

They do seem to use feature branches to me.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: What Tim said, we just make a new branch for each feature.

posts.name: Ryan Morash
posts.cooked:
These are our branches currently: image 282×698 15.4 KB

image 282×698 15.4 KB

image 282×698 15.4 KB

posts.name: Jeremy Reed
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

Option 4: Branch for each feature, like any other professional software team

This is the approach we take as well though the kids may not be as familiar with the Git side of it all, since is a bit rougher to teach when most of them have never programmed before.

Providing the experiences of what they are likely going to face in a professional setting is a much more valuable experience long term. Though I don’t think deep diving into branch strategies is beneficial for the level of work done in FRC , some variation trunk based seems to be what most teams follow from what I’ve seen.

The other thing that I keep trying to implement as a sanity check more for myself then anything else is tagging the committed code for each event. so I can go back and say “This worked at Week 2 what changed to why it doesn’t work at week 4?” This also gives a good idea of who the code evolved to help teach different areas in the coming years and start from a more refined standard as well.

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
Agreed. Branches for tiny teams is just adding unnecessary complexity. But the commits have to have useful tags/descriptions so you can find changes.

But once you get enough students that they break into separate projects, then branch on feature.

posts.name: gurellia53
posts.cooked: trunk-based development

posts.name: Ryan Morash
posts.cooked: I should note this is with two students programming, RyanTest is mine

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Branches for each piece of discrete work.  It may be for a new subsytem, or for changing the motor controller of a subsystem.     Definitely not for a contributor and branches go away when the PR to main is merged to encourage fresh branches from main.

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked:
Branching for the sake for branching adds additional overhead and reduces developer speed, especially for students. In my experience, working on main and having students continuously push and pull small changes enables faster development with shared features and more collaboration on those features.

Large more purposeful refactors may need branches.

ArchdukeTim:

Branch for each feature, like any other professional software team

Branches are exceedingly rare for development at Google and other places with similar development styles.

posts.name: allison zhang
posts.cooked:
pretty much what we, albeit an inexperienced programming team, do.

we only branch when we’re experimenting big changes and want to keep a version that works (such as redoing swerve, adding vision, etc.)

posts.name: Tayler Uva
posts.cooked:
We have a larger software team, so we branch for each new feature or piece of work. For us, every branch must be tested in either sim, on the bot, or both before it goes into main. We want our main branch to always be as competition ready as possible. This strategy also works great for tracking what is getting done and what’s in progress.

Once a branch has implemented its features, students submit a PR that I or one of our advanced students review line by line to ensure coding standards consistency and try to find any bugs. This also works great for when students are stuck as I can see exactly what bits of code they changed regardless of number of commits (they may commit in parts as parts are working).

This is identical to the git strategy we use at my work so it’s also great work experience!

posts.name: Jack Doherty
posts.cooked:
We branch primarily based on features. It definitely adds additional overhead and complexity to learning “how” to be a part of any of our software projects, but it:

Is a work style/skill they should know before college

Better promotes code review thru PRs

Helps me (and other mentors) keep track of the chaos

gurellia53:

trunk-based development

Thanks for the reminder to go back to work and update trunk

posts.name: Brock Atchison
posts.cooked:
though the kids may not be as familiar with the Git side of it all, since is a bit rougher to teach when most of them have never programmed before.

This is only my third season as a programming mentor, but Git and the concept of source control definitely seems to be the most challenging thing to teach.

The other thing that I keep trying to implement as a sanity check more for myself then anything else is tagging the committed code for each event. so I can go back and say “This worked at Week 2 what changed to why it doesn’t work at week 4?”

This is very similar to a strategy that we use, but since we have a habit of changing code at competitions, we go even a bit more granular. We create a branch for the competition (just for the separation from main and to be able to more easily see what was done at the competition). Then we tag the commit that was used for a specific match so we can also compare to find out what may have happened if we break something between matches.

posts.name: coderkevin
posts.cooked:
Short-running PR branches that are deleted after merge. PRs are reviewed by Programming Lead or Programming Mentor before merging. Nobody leaves the shop without pushing their code up to their PR first.

Pet peeve of mine: 99.9% of all HS and College-level classes teach nothing about source control. By teaching our programmers how to use Git and GitHub properly, we do a lot to prepare them for working in the software industry.

posts.name: Tayler Uva
posts.cooked: 100%! I have to teach git to my students AND my coworkers

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: This not the best way ever but I push right into main and use git as a backup incase the laptop breaks. BUT , I do branch right before comp when everything works well incase I do something at comp that makes it go haywire.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
Pushing everything straight to main

Seriously, we have a team of <5 people, and for us, branches just cause headaches.  Build seasons move fast, and everyone wants to edit RobotContainer.java.  Occasionally breaking things is better than fighting with merge conflicts everytime someone needs to test on the robot.

data.fancy_title: How do you collaborate using Git?
